    <item>
      <title>Number of suicides in England and Wales reaches 20-year high</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/number-of-suicides-in-england-and-wales-last-year-reaches-20-year-high</link>
      <description><p>Prince William meets mental health charity after figures show number of female suicides rose sharply in 2015</p><p>The number of women who killed themselves rose sharply last year as the total number of suicides for England and Wales reached a 20-year high. There were 3,899 rulings of suicide in coroners’ courts in 2015, according to figures released on Thursday by the Ministry of Justice – more than for any 12-month period since 1995, when the data series began. </p><p>While the number of men found to have killed themselves fell to 2,997, 23 fewer than in 2014, the number of women increased by 70 to 902. The fewest suicides were in 2007, when 3,007 such verdicts were recorded, and the number has risen consistently since then.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/number-of-suicides-in-england-and-wales-last-year-reaches-20-year-high">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Olive Garden protests target drugged chickens and fair wages</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/12/olive-garden-protests-chicken-fair-wages</link>
      <description><p>Darden Restaurants, the largest full-service restaurant group in the US, is facing pressure to use antibiotic-free meat and pay better wages</p><p>Dozens of protesters picketed Olive Garden restaurants in seven cities on Thursday, including New York and Los Angeles, delivering a petition with 130,000 signatures that asks the chain to serve more vegetables, use meat raised with minimal use of antibiotics and pay its employees fair wages.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2015/dec/28/egg-industry-mcdonalds-free-range-hens-dunkin-donuts-general-mills-nestle">Why the egg industry is scrambling to set hens free</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2015/oct/23/chipotles-corporate-social-responsibility-mcdonalds-gmo">Chipotle's silence on sustainability practices make it a target for CSR advocates</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/12/olive-garden-protests-chicken-fair-wages">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Zika virus makes Rio Olympics a threat in Brazil and abroad, health expert says</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/rio-olympics-zika-amir-attaran-public-health-threat</link>
      <description><p>Amir Attaran calls for postponement or moving of Games and says biggest risk is spreading the virus to countries without adequate healthcare infrastructure </p><p>As Brazil reels from a spiraling political crisis and its deepest recession in decades, a public health specialist in Canada has added to the country’s woes with a high-profile call for the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/olympic-games-2016">2016 summer Olympics</a> – slated to kick off in Rio de Janeiro in early August – to be postponed or moved due to the Zika outbreak.<br></p><p>“But for the Games, would anyone recommend sending an extra half a million visitors into Brazil right now?” Canadian professor Amir Attaran, whose research areas include population health and global development policy, asked this week in a commentary <a href="http://harvardpublichealthreview.org/off-the-podium-why-rios-2016-olympic-games-must-not-proceed/#_edn5">published in the Harvard Public Health Review</a>.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/27/rio-2016-olympic-games-100-days-to-go-brazil-controversy-legacy">100 days until Rio 2016: 'It will be a great party, with a garbage legacy'</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/rio-olympics-zika-amir-attaran-public-health-threat">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>NHS whistleblower 'was treated unfairly' after alleging death rate-fixing</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/nhs-whistleblower-treated-unfairly-alleging-death-rate-fixing-wolverhampton</link>
      <description><p>Review finds Royal Wolverhampton NHS Trust was not fair to Sandra Haynes-Kirkbright after she alleged coding flaws</p><p>An NHS whistleblower who claimed she was treated badly by a hospital trust after alleging it had been fixing its death rates was treated unfairly, a report has found.<br></p><p>Sandra Haynes-Kirkbright was head of clinical coding at the Royal Wolverhampton NHS Trust when she first alleged there were systematic flaws in its data leading to overpayments to the hospital trust.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/nhs-whistleblower-treated-unfairly-alleging-death-rate-fixing-wolverhampton">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Prince Charles: I use homeopathy in animals to cut antibiotic use</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/prince-charles-use-homeopathy-in-animals-to-cut-antibiotic-use</link>
      <description><p>Homeopathy sceptic Dame Sally Davies among delegates to hear prince say he treats his cows with alternative medicine</p><p>Prince Charles has proposed a solution to the growing crisis of antibiotic over-use in animals and humans, telling an international gathering of scientists and government officials in London that he treats his own cows and sheep with homeopathy.</p><p>In front of the government’s chief medical officer, Dame Sally Davies, who once told a parliamentary committee that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/may/08/jeremy-hunt-homeopathy-studies-chief-medical-officer">homeopathy in humans was “rubbish”</a> and that she was “perpetually surprised that homeopathy is available on the NHS”, the prince explained to delegates from 20 nations and organisations why he had turned to homeopathic remedies for animals.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/jun/04/black-spider-memos-prince-charles-lobbied-homeopathy-funding-nhs">'Black spider memos': Prince Charles lobbied over NHS homeopathy funding</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/dec/08/antibiotic-use-food-fuels-humans-resistance-vital-drugs-report">Antibiotic use in food fuels resistance to vital drugs – report</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/prince-charles-use-homeopathy-in-animals-to-cut-antibiotic-use">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Britain’s accountability problem – hospitals are just the start | Anne Perkins</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/hillsborough-hospitals-public-bodies</link>
      <description><p>If holding vital public bodies to account is a mark of a civilised, functioning democracy, we’re not in a good place</p><p>Margaret Aspinall, whose 18-year-old son James <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/apr/27/hillsborough-families-applauded-at-liverpool-vigil-inquest">died in the Hillsborough tragedy</a>, addressed a meeting in parliament on Tuesday. She spoke at the launch of Andy Burnham’s <a href="http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/andy-burnham-proposes-major-reforms-11313170">new campaign</a> for stronger police accountability. The parliamentary and health service ombudsman (PHSO) has just <a href="http://www.ombudsman.org.uk/reports-and-consultations/reports/health/a-report-of-investigations-into-unsafe-discharge-from-hospital">published a shaming report</a> on the way vulnerable patients are sometimes discharged from hospital. Earlier in the week, health thinktank <a href="http://www.kingsfund.org.uk/blog/2016/04/readiness-to-change">the King’s Fund</a> heard that there was a serious shortage of senior managers prepared to take on the thankless task of running an NHS trust.</p><p>Each of these is important in themselves. Each of these says something troubling about how public bodies are held to account.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/hospital-policy-older-people-dying-ombudsman">My mother’s treatment in hospital opened my eyes to a policy of shameful neglect | Joan Smith</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/11/hillsborough-verdict-sparks-call-to-rebalance-police-and-criminal-justice-system">Hillsborough verdict sparks call to rebalance police and criminal justice system</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/hillsborough-hospitals-public-bodies">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Indian doctors raise IVF concerns after woman in her 70s gives birth</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/indian-doctors-ivf-woman-70s-gives-birth-fertility-treatment-daljinder-kaur</link>
      <description><p>Doctors call for upper age limit for fertility treatment after Daljinder Kaur has first child after 46 years of marriage</p><p>Doctors in India have raised concerns about IVF treatment in the country, after a couple in their 70s had their first child after 46 years of marriage. Daljinder Kaur, who does not have a birth certificate but is thought be in her 70s, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/indian-woman-in-her-70s-gives-birth-to-healthy-baby-boy">gave birth to a boy</a> last month after two years of fertility treatment using donor eggs at a clinic in the northern state of Haryana.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/10/foul-reign-of-the-biological-clock">The foul reign of the biological clock | Moira Weigel</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/20/are-you-worried-about-your-fertility-young-people-share-their-stories">Are you worried about your fertility? Young people share their stories</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/shortcuts/2016/may/11/being-an-older-mother-i-love-it">I’m an older mother – and I bloody love it</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/indian-doctors-ivf-woman-70s-gives-birth-fertility-treatment-daljinder-kaur">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Adam McKay defends Ronald Reagan 'Alzheimer’s comedy'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/adam-mckay-ronald-reagan-alzheimers-comedy-will-ferrell</link>
      <description><p>The Big Short director says ‘deification of Reagan’ is responsible for backlash against the Will Ferrell film plans </p><p>The Oscar-winning film-maker Adam McKay has defended plans for a controversial comedy about Ronald Reagan suffering from Alzheimer’s disease after his producing partner <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/29/will-ferrell-backs-out-ronald-reagan-alzheimers-comedy">Will Ferrell was forced to step away</a> from the project in the wake of rightwing outrage.</p><p>Adam McKay, known for The Big Short and Anchorman, was due to produce Reagan through the Gary Sanchez production company he runs with Ferrell. The erstwhile Saturday Night Live comic was in line to play the former president, but walked away following a media furore.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/29/will-ferrell-backs-out-ronald-reagan-alzheimers-comedy">Will Ferrell backs out of Ronald Reagan's Alzheimer's comedy</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/01/ronald-reagan-will-ferrell-alzheimers-satire-comedy">The joke isn't on Ronald Reagan's illness, but on America for elevating him</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/adam-mckay-ronald-reagan-alzheimers-comedy-will-ferrell">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>There’s nothing wrong with having a baby in your 70s | Aarathi Prasad</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/daljinder-kaur-baby-70s</link>
      <description>Any woman should be able to make good decisions about her body – and if Daljinder Kaur is strong enough to fulfil her parenting dream perhaps we should lay off<p>The birth of Armaan Singh Gill, a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/indian-woman-in-her-70s-gives-birth-to-healthy-baby-boy" title="">2kg boy, to Daljinder Kaur</a> was announced by Indian and international media this week. Though she has no birth certificate, Kaur, estimated to be 72, is thought to be the world’s oldest mother. Armaan was her first child. He was the result of her third round of IVF, using donor eggs and possibly donor sperm as well.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/indian-woman-in-her-70s-gives-birth-to-healthy-baby-boy">Indian woman in her 70s gives birth to healthy baby boy</a> </p><p>Recent ONS data has shown steady rises in the number of women giving birth to first children later in life</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/mar/01/fertility-problems-failure-conceive-pregnancy">My fertility problems made me feel like a failure | Sarah Fletcher</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/daljinder-kaur-baby-70s">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why not date someone with ME? We’re tough survivors | Anonymous</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/date-me-chronic-fatigue-syndrome-illness</link>
      <description>My partner listed my chronic fatigue syndrome as a reason not to be with me. But my illness is not who I am<p>It is 1am. I am sitting opposite my partner in the kitchen, and they have not stopped talking for the last 45 minutes. Not even to draw breath. It’s more a flow of sudden, unbridled frustration, anger and confusion compounded by one gut-wrenching sentence: “I just can’t tolerate it any more.” This is the moment I realise we are in serious trouble. Because somewhere between instantly upgrading your devices and swapping providers to get the best deal for your money, we seem to have lost our capacity to tolerate imperfection anywhere else, even in our relationships.</p><p>One of my imperfections is a condition I have suffered from for half my life – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/chronic-fatigue-syndrome" title="">myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME) or chronic fatigue syndrome</a>. I was severely ill for most of my teens, wheelchair-bound and unable to look after myself. But by 30 I had almost completely recovered, I lived alone, forging a successful career in a high-stress environment. If you met me now, you would have no idea just how ill I had been.</p><p>My ME doesn’t dictate what music I listen to, what films I enjoy, or my love and affection for my partner</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/feb/15/it-was-like-being-buried-alive-victim-of-chronic-fatigue-syndrome">‘It was like being buried alive’: battle to recover from chronic fatigue syndrome</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/date-me-chronic-fatigue-syndrome-illness">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Shaking, crying, panic – the trauma of a benefits assessment with PTSD | Frances Ryan</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/benefits-assessment-ptsd-benefit</link>
      <description><p>After a distressing experience she can’t even remember, Lucia’s PIP was cut. She suffered a relapse and, like dominos, more benefits were taken away</p><p>Looking through the letter marked “Atos healthcare”, Lucia – who has severe post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and anxiety – can only remember fragments of the assessment for personal independence payments (PIP) she had two months ago.</p><p>A normal day is often hard enough for the 34-year-old. Lucia’s husband Daniel, a former hospital administrator, had to leave work three years ago to become her full-time carer. She’s been relying on disability living allowance (DLA) – the benefit the government is replacing with PIP – for six years to pay for weekly therapy sessions. On the days running up to her Atos medical, Lucia tells me she “wasn’t functioning” because of the stress: she couldn’t get dressed, wash, or leave the house.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/apr/11/iain-duncan-smith-pip-payments-punish-poor-ill-dying">Personal independence payments are a punishment of the poor and ill | Polly Toynbee</a> </p><p>Lucia knows their money will soon run out and the couple is now cutting back on food.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/11/big-benefits-myth-tories-half-families-low-incomes-not-claiming-welfare">£13bn in unclaimed welfare? It’s just fuel for the Tories’ Big Benefits Myth | Frances Ryan</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/benefits-assessment-ptsd-benefit">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>WHO recommends shorter drug regimen for multi-drug resistant TB</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/shorter-treatment-multi-drug-resistant-tb-raises-hopes-who</link>
      <description><p>New diagnostic test and nine-month course of treatment may help save thousands of lives, health body says<br></p><p>A new drug regime that shortens the treatment for multi-drug resistant tuberculosis from two years to nine months has been recommended for use by the World Health Organisation, raising hopes that hundreds of thousands of people will stay the course and be cured.</p><p>About 480,000 people are estimated by the WHO to have this form of the infectious disease, which has been found in every country in the world and kills 190,000 every year. MDR-TB cannot be cured by the standard six-month regimen of antibiotics because the bacteria have become resistant to some or all of the drugs, meaning they no longer work.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/mar/24/pills-treat-tb-research-multi-drug-resistant-tuberculosis">14,600 pills over two years – there has to be a better way to treat TB | Philippe Douste-Blazy</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/shorter-treatment-multi-drug-resistant-tb-raises-hopes-who">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Air pollution health timebomb poses a major threat to development</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/12/air-pollution-health-timebomb-poses-a-major-threat-to-development-who</link>
      <description><p>A World Health Organisation report shows little escape from poisoned air in poorer countries, resulting in 3 million premature deaths worldwide a year<br></p><p> Countries are finding that the urban economic development to which they aspire brings poisoned air, ill-health, massive costs, a low quality of life and, probably, an early death for a very great many people.</p><p>That is the stark conclusion from a reading of the <a href="http://www.who.int/phe/en/">new database of outdoor air quality</a> from the World Health Organisation (WHO), for 3,000 of the world’s cities. While millions of people in rich countries suffer the cancers, heart and respiratory diseases that air pollution brings, the levels of air pollution in many Asian and African cities are said to be five or even 10 times worse.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-rising-at-an-alarming-rate-in-worlds-cities">Air pollution rising at an 'alarming rate' in world's cities</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/12/air-pollution-health-timebomb-poses-a-major-threat-to-development-who">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>NHS records worst performance for third month in a row</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/nhs-worst-performance-hospital-targets-emergency-patients</link>
      <description><p>Hospitals missed key targets to treat emergency patients and those waiting for planned operations </p><p>The NHS has recorded its worst performance for the third month in a row, with hospitals missing key targets to treat A&amp;E patients and those waiting for planned operations as well as people suspected to have cancer. </p><p>During March hospitals struggled to cope with an increase in demand for care while ambulance services also failed to reach record numbers of patients quickly enough after a 999 call. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/12/nhs-worst-performance-hospital-targets-emergency-patients">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I am dying and I want everyone to talk about it</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2016/may/12/i-am-dying-want-talk-family-carer-doctors-death</link>
      <description><p>This is a plea to my family, carer, doctors and specialists: start talking about death as much as you do about life. Is that too much to ask?</p><p>For 16 years I have known I’m terminally ill. I’ve had to come to terms with the fact I won’t grow old with my husband, or see my grandchildren become teenagers. I’ve seen my body change; I am slowly wasting away. I have faced the mental struggle of being told I’ve 18 months to live, only to see myself outlive the prognosis. I take 38 tablets every single day and rely on an oxygen tank to breathe. My spine is crumbling; I’ve shrunk by two inches. My skin is covered in painful psoriasis, and I have a growth in my stomach the size of a 30-week pregnancy.</p><p>And yet, despite this, my biggest challenge is trying to talk to you about the fact that soon, I will die. There’s something about death that people can’t face. We thrive on life; we celebrate it at every opportunity whether it’s a birthday or a christening. And yet, even though everyone who lives will die, death remains the elephant in the room. It’s a stigma, something we need to tiptoe around and leave to care professionals.</p><p>I’ve planned my funeral. Everything is organised other than the type of coffin I’ll have</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2016/feb/03/casualty-cpr-fails-cancer-doctors-let-patients-die">This is not Casualty – in real life CPR is brutal and usually fails</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2016/may/12/i-am-dying-want-talk-family-carer-doctors-death">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>My mother’s treatment in hospital opened my eyes to a policy of shameful neglect | Joan Smith</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/hospital-policy-older-people-dying-ombudsman</link>
      <description><p>No one consulted me when my 89-year-old mother was discharged from hospital. The NHS ombudsman’s report shows this is happening all over Britain</p><p>The first shock came when I found out my mother was dying. The second was when I discovered that she had been discharged from hospital without my knowledge. My mother was 89, and had dementia, lung cancer and secondary tumours on the brain. I had pleaded with the hospital not to take any decisions without first speaking to me, but they ignored me, as they had done since she was admitted as an emergency six days earlier.</p><p>What happened to my mother is far from unusual, I’m sorry to say. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/10/nhs-discharge-system-failing-elderly-patients-says-nhs-ombudsman-report-vulnerable-hospital">Elderly people are being discharged from hospital too soon</a>, according to an excoriating report from Dame Julie Mellor, the parliamentary and health service ombudsman. It describes the experience of nine patients and their families in harrowing detail, including the case of a woman in her 90s who collapsed and died in her granddaughter’s arms after doctors failed to diagnose an infection and sent her home. Dame Julie says these cases represent only a fraction of the total number.</p><p>Now people are living longer, many of us will go through the grim experience of witnessing the decline of a relative</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/10/nhs-discharge-system-failing-elderly-patients-says-nhs-ombudsman-report-vulnerable-hospital">NHS discharge system failing too many elderly patients, says watchdog</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/hospital-policy-older-people-dying-ombudsman">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Eastbourne a surprise name among UK's most polluted towns and cities</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/eastbourne-a-surprise-name-among-uks-most-polluted-towns-and-cities</link>
      <description><p>Port Talbot seems obvious, but World Health Organisation data shows south coast town registers high levels of two tiny types of particulate pollution <br></p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-how-does-it-affect-you">Air pollution: how does it affect you? </a></li></ul><p>It’s perhaps no surprise that Port Talbot, home to one of Europe’s biggest steelworks with thousands of tonnes of iron ore imported to its docks every year, tops the list of the UK’s most polluted towns and cities. </p><p>But Eastbourne, home to the women’s tennis tournament and located at the end of the South Downs national park, is not an obvious candidate for the top 10 of the worst UK towns and cities for two tiny types of particulate pollution. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/eastbourne-a-surprise-name-among-uks-most-polluted-towns-and-cities">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Air pollution rising at an 'alarming rate' in world's cities</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-rising-at-an-alarming-rate-in-worlds-cities</link>
      <description><p>Outdoor pollution has risen 8% in five years with fast-growing cities in the developing world worst affected, WHO data shows</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-how-does-it-affect-you">Air pollution: how does it affect you?</a><br></li></ul><p><br>Outdoor air pollution has grown 8% globally in the past five years, with billions of people around the world now exposed to dangerous air, <a href="http://www.who.int/phe">according to new data</a> from more than 3,000 cities compiled by the World Health Organisation (WHO). </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/which-are-the-worlds-two-most-polluted-cities-and-why">Which are the world's two most polluted cities – and why?</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-how-does-it-affect-you">Air pollution: how does it affect you?</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/eastbourne-a-surprise-name-among-uks-most-polluted-towns-and-cities">Eastbourne a surprise name among UK's most polluted towns and cities</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-rising-at-an-alarming-rate-in-worlds-cities">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Which are the world's two most polluted cities  – and why?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/which-are-the-worlds-two-most-polluted-cities-and-why</link>
      <description><p>Two cities – one in Iran and another in Nigeria – can claim title because WHO measures pollution in two different ways</p><p>The new WHO database of worldwide air pollution measures it in two different ways, and as a result two cities – one in Iran and another in Nigeria – can lay claim to the unenviable title of world’s most polluted city.</p><p>It all comes down to which minute particles, or particulate matter (PM), in the air are being measured. These particles are between 2.5 and 10 microns in diameter, roughly 30 times smaller than the width of a human hair. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/people-may-be-breathing-in-microplastics-health-expert-warns">People may be breathing in microplastics, health expert warns</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/how-giant-air-freshener-could-save-polluted-cities">How a giant air freshener could save our polluted cities</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/20/dangerous-air-pollution-us-population-report">More than half US population lives amid dangerous air pollution, report warns</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/which-are-the-worlds-two-most-polluted-cities-and-why">Continue reading...</a></description>
